story.headline: Manila: Ground Zero for the World's Deadliest Typhoons
story.summary: The Philippines is the most typhoon-exposed nation on Earth, with Manila and surrounding regions bearing the brunt. In late 2025, six typhoons struck within 30 days — an unprecedented super-cluster — pushing the Philippines to the top of the Climate Risk Index.
story.climateImpact: Warmer oceans intensify typhoons, while sea level rise amplifies flooding in low-lying Metro Manila. Climate change is increasing both the frequency of extreme typhoons and the speed of rapid intensification.
causeEffect: The Philippines lies in the world's most active typhoon corridor
Warming seas increase typhoon wind speeds and rainfall
Rapid intensification gives less time for evacuation
Metro Manila's 14 million people are highly exposed to storm surge
Repeated destruction traps communities in poverty cycles
story.scaleContext: The Philippines averages 20 typhoons per year, with 8-9 making landfall. Typhoon Haiyan (2013) killed over 6,300 people. The 2025 super-cluster affected over 10 million people in 30 days.
story.outlook: The Climate Risk Index ranks the Philippines as the most vulnerable nation in 2026. Investment in early warning systems and resilient infrastructure is critical.
